We have 200 mbps+ downlink speeds here, and there are faster domestic options locally. Latency to the ISP server, is usually around 9 to 18 ms. It will be interesting to see what Starlink will do, when it's fully operational. Latency will be around at least 0.5 seconds, but the transfer speeds could be very competitive.

The Starlink satellites are flaring quite spectacularly, up to around 2nd or 3rd Magnitude. Astrophotographers are going to hate that, but they're also stimulating people to 'get out and get looking up' at the night sky. They've spread out around a whole orbit now, 2nd June, 2019, so online orbital predictions about the 'first' and the 'last' one are becoming meaningless. They're visible beyond overhead at times, and pretty much right through the Summer night, here in Central England.

RGV= Rio Grande Valley which encompasses the 4 south most counties in Texas. Willacy, Hidalgo, Start, and Cameron, which is where SpaceX Boca Chica is. Basically when you drive down here and start seeing lots of palm trees you're in the RGV. Then another 45 minutes to SpaceX.

Tim, what you're doing is absolutely fantastic. I've always had a deep passion for rockets, rocket launches, and space in general. I've learned so much more about all of those things thanks to you and your channel. So please keep doing what you're doing, and thank you from Pittsburgh.
Sincerely,
Jeremy Shaffer

They did NOT pitch while deploying the satellites and at least the minutes after because you can see them staying in the field of view of the camera. If they would have decided to deploy them while pitching that stack would have been a bunch of crap now ;-)
They just released them and they slowly started to seperate from each other.

So how do they get them into different orbits now?  I know they have de-orbit thrusters but since they released them all together like that while they will separate ever so slightly over time wont they all just be in basically the same orbit?  I know they could change their position in the orbit with very minimal thrust but they can't really change the angle any significant amount can they?  And yes I know this batch is experimental but it represents how they will launch future sets of these as well.  Or is this the point.  This set of 60 will eventually be spread out around the orbit on this inclination and then the next set will be on a different inclination.
Thanks for the broadcast Tim! Can't wait for the Raptor video!
